journal-meta.journal-title: Ergonomics in Design: The Quarterly of Human Factors Applications

body.p: The following is a list of design guidelines that can contribute to improving patient safety.

sec.title: Empirically evaluate existing and future interfaces for their suitability to user task
sec.p: Wiseman, Cox, and Brumby (2013) conducted an analysis of the patterns of digits and numbers used when programming infusion devices across multiple wards at a hospital over 5 years. They found that zero is the most commonly entered digit, the most common values for rate and drug volume are round numbers ending in zero, and the third most common value for rate is 999. The authors concluded that the current design of number entry interfaces in infusion pumps is not optimized for usage patterns. They suggest the following guidelines when designing number entry interfaces:

list-item.p: Reduce the number of key presses for frequently used numbers (e.g., one key press per zero),
have dedicated buttons for frequently used multidigit numbers (1000, 100, and 50), and (c) make the user request functionalities that are rarely used (e.g., decimal point) to prevent slips.

sec.title: Use the percent format to communicate health risk information
sec.p: As patients are becoming more involved in their own health care, it is important that they accurately understand health risk information. Fausset and Rogers (2012) examined the comprehension of health risk probabilities by younger and older adults. They found that using a percent format (e.g., 10%) when communicating health risk information is more likely to be understood by younger and older adults compared with a frequency format (e.g., 1 in 10).

sec.title: Design instructional aids (and not just interfaces) using HF/E principles
sec.p: User error during endoscope processing can cause infection that can affect patient safety. The main sources of user error are considered to be lack of visibility of a part or tool in the endoscope, high memory demands (attributable to multitude parts and sequential steps; conflicting visual aids), and a lack of visual feedback signaling the successful completion of a step. Jolly, Hildebrand, and Branaghan (2012) used the following guidelines to redesign instructional aids for endoscope processing:

list-item.p: Position visuals in close proximity to text,
provide text that can be read quickly,
break down tasks into basic elements,
put key information in an easily accessible format,
highlight relationships and differences between elements, and
use color that accommodates for color-blindness.

sec.p: The authors found that participants who were given the instructional aid that was designed employing human factors/ergonomics principles were able to successfully complete the reprocessing task versus those who used the manufacturer-provided visual aids.

sec.title: Quantify patient migration to optimize hospital bed design
sec.p: Pressure ulcers and skin tears are increasing in prevalence in hospitals. Kotowski, Davis, Wiggermann, and Williamson (2013) discussed how net displacement, cumulative movement, and torso compression can be used as metrics to design changes in bed frames, bed articulations, and mattress inflation. Such changes can reduce risk to the patient for pressure ulcers and skin tears and also reduce the risk of low-back injuries among nurses.
